Labeling Schemes with Queries

Amos Korman Information Systems Group, Faculty of IE&M, The Technion, Haifa, 32000 Israel. E-mail:pandit@tx.technion.ac.il. Supported in part at the Technion by an Aly Kaufman fellowship.    Shay Kutten Information Systems Group, Faculty of IE&M, The Technion, Haifa, 32000 Israel. E-mail: kutten@ie.technion.ac.il. Fax: +972 (4) 829 5688. Phone: +972 (4) 829 4505. Supported in part by a grant from the Israeli Ministry for Science and Technology.

We study the question of “how robust are the known lower bounds of labeling schemes when one increases the number of consulted labels”. Let f𝑓fitalic_f be a function on pairs of vertices. An f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme for a family of graphs ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F labels the vertices of all graphs in ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F such that for every graph G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F and every two vertices u,v∈G𝑢𝑣𝐺u,v\in Gitalic_u , italic_v ∈ italic_G, the value f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) can be inferred by merely inspecting the labels of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v.

This paper introduces a natural generalization: the notion of f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling schemes with queries, in which the value f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) can be inferred by inspecting not only the labels of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v but possibly the labels of some additional vertices. We show that inspecting the label of a single additional vertex (one query) enables us to reduce the label size of many labeling schemes significantly. In particular, we show that to support the distance function on n𝑛nitalic_n-node trees as well as the flow function on n𝑛nitalic_n-node general graphs, O⁢(log⁡n+log⁡W)𝑂𝑛𝑊O(\log n+\log W)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_W )-bit labels are sufficient and necessary, where W𝑊Witalic_W is the maximum (integral) capacity of an edge. We note that it was shown that any labeling scheme (without queries) supporting either the flow function on general graphs or the distance function on trees, must have label size Ω⁢(log2⁡n+log⁡n⁢log⁡W)Ωsuperscript2𝑛𝑛𝑊\Omega(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)roman_Ω ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W ). Using a single query, we also show a routing labeling scheme in the fixed-port model using O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels, while the lower bound on the label size of any such routing labeling scheme (without queries) is Ω⁢(log2⁡n/log⁡log⁡n)Ωsuperscript2𝑛𝑛\Omega({\log^{2}n}/{\log\log n})roman_Ω ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ). We note that all our labeling schemes with queries have asymptotically optimal label size.

We then show several extensions. In particular, we show that our labeling schemes with queries on trees can be extended to the dynamic scenario by some adaptations of known model translation methods. Second, we show that the study of the queries model can help with the traditional model too. That is, using ideas from our routing labeling scheme with one query, we show how to construct a 3-approximation routing scheme without queries in the fixed-port model with Θ⁢(log⁡n)Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels. Finally, we turn to a non-distributed environment and first translate known results on finding NCA to supporting distance queries. We then use the above to show that one can preprocess a general weighted graph using almost linear space so that flow queries can be answered in almost constant time.

1 Introduction

Background:

Network representations play a major role in many domains of computer science, ranging from data structures, graph algorithms, and combinatorial optimization to databases, distributed computing, and communication networks. In most traditional network representations, the names or identifiers given to the vertices betray no useful information, and they serve only as pointers to entries in the data structure, which forms a global representation of the network. Recently, quite a few papers studied methods for representing network properties by assigning informative labels to the vertices of the network (see e.g., [43, 9, 32, 39, 51, 5, 24]).

Let f𝑓fitalic_f be a function on pairs of vertices (e.g., distance). Informally, the goal of an f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme is to label the vertices of a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G in such a way that for every two vertices u,v∈G𝑢𝑣𝐺u,v\in Gitalic_u , italic_v ∈ italic_G, the value f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) (e.g., the distance between u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v) can be inferred by merely inspecting the labels of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v.

Of course, this can be done trivially using labels that are large enough (e.g., every label includes the description of the whole graph). Therefore, the main focus of the research concerning labeling schemes is to minimize the amount of information (the sizes of the labels) required. Informally, an f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme can be viewed as a way of distributing the graph structure information concerning f𝑓fitalic_f to the vertices of the graph, using small chunks of information per vertex.

This paper introduces the notion of f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling schemes with queries which generalizes the notion of f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling schemes. The idea is to distribute the global information (relevant to f𝑓fitalic_f) to the vertices, in such a way that f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) can be inferred by inspecting not only the labels of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v but possibly the labels of some additional vertices. We note that all the constructions given in this paper calculate f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ) by inspecting the labels of three vertices (u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v above, and some w𝑤witalic_w). That is, given the labels of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v, we first find a vertex w𝑤witalic_w and then consult its label to derive f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ).

Our paper demonstrate that the task of distributing the graph structure to the vertices using short labels is very sensitive to the model used. In particular, in order to calculate f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ), if one is allowed to consult the labels of three vertices instead of two, then the sizes of the labels can drop considerably, in orders of magnitude. Moreover, our query labeling schemes can be obtained using simple methods. This turns out to be useful, when we go back to the traditional model (without queries) and apply ideas from one of our methods to construct a new result in the traditional model.

Most previous research concerning distributed network representations considered the static scenario, in which the topology of the underlying network is fixed. However, recent papers tackle the more difficult task of labeling dynamic networks in a distributed fashion. Such labeling methods should, of course, be dynamic too. We show that the effect of introducing a query to the dynamic case is similar to the effect on the static case. That is, we modify the model translation methods of [38] and [42], and then use them to extend our static labeling schemes with queries on trees, to the dynamic scenario. We then show that the sizes of the resulted schemes are smaller than those of the schemes for the older model. The reduction in the label size is similar to the reduction in the static case.

Finally, we show that our methods are also useful in the non-distributed environment.

Related work:

In this subsection we mostly survey results concerning labeling schemes (with no queries). However, let us first mention an area of research (namely, overlay and Peer to Peer networks) that may serve as a practical motivation for our work, and for some other studies concerning labeling schemes. We stress, though, that the main motivation for this paper is theoretical.

When the third vertex w𝑤witalic_w (mentioned above) is near by to u𝑢uitalic_u, it may be quite cheap for u𝑢uitalic_u to access the main memory at w𝑤witalic_w, sometimes even cheaper than consulting the disk at u𝑢uitalic_u itself. See, for example [47, 37]. Indeed, some of our schemes below are based on such a “near by” w𝑤witalic_w. Even when w𝑤witalic_w is remote, accessing it may be cheap in some overlay networks. The main overhead there is finding w𝑤witalic_w (which can be done in our constructions by u𝑢uitalic_u using v𝑣vitalic_v’s label) and creating the connection to it. Such models are presented explicitly, e.g. in [34, 16, 2, 54], where such remote accesses are used to construct and to use overlay data structures. Famous overlay data structures that can fit such models appear for example in [56, 63, 48, 26, 49]. In some of these overlay networks, a vertex w𝑤witalic_w is addressed by its contents. This may motivate common labeling schemes that assume content addressability.

Implicit labeling schemes were first introduced in [11, 12, 43]. Labeling schemes supporting the adjacency and ancestry functions on trees were investigated in [43, 9, 44, 7, 8].

Distance labeling schemes were studied in [50, 40, 32, 31, 29, 44, 59, 18, 4]. In particular, [50] showed that the family of n𝑛nitalic_n vertex weighted trees with integer edge capacity of at most W𝑊Witalic_W enjoys a scheme using O⁢(log2⁡n+log⁡n⁢log⁡W)𝑂superscript2𝑛𝑛𝑊O(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W )-bit labels. This bound was proven in [32] to be asymptotically optimal.

Labeling schemes for routing on trees were investigated in a number of papers [55, 62, 15, 21, 23] until finally optimized in [24, 25, 61]. For the designer port model, in which the designer of the scheme can freely enumerate the port numbers of the nodes, [24] shows how to construct a routing scheme using labels of O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits on n𝑛nitalic_n-node trees. In the adversary port model, in which the port numbers are fixed by an adversary, they show how to construct a routing scheme using labels of O⁢(log2⁡n/log⁡log⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛𝑛O(\log^{2}n/\log\log n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ) bits on n𝑛nitalic_n-node trees. In [25] they show that both label sizes are asymptotically optimal. Independently, a routing scheme for trees using (1+o⁢(1))⁢log⁡n1𝑜1𝑛(1+o(1))\log n( 1 + italic_o ( 1 ) ) roman_log italic_n-bit labels was introduced in [61] for the designer port model.

Two variants of labeling schemes supporting the nearest common ancestor (NCA) function in trees appear in the literature. In an id-NCA labeling schemes, the vertices of the input graph are assumed to have disjoint identifiers (using O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits) given by an adversary. The goal of an id-NCA labeling scheme is to label the vertices such that given the labels of any two vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v, one can find the identifier of the NCA of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v. Static labeling schemes on trees supporting the separation level and id-NCA functions were given in [51] using Θ⁢(log2⁡n)Θsuperscript2𝑛\Theta(\log^{2}n)roman_Θ ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n )-bit labels. The second variant considered is the label-NCA labeling scheme, whose goal is to label the vertices such that given the labels of any two vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v, one can find the label (and not the pre-given identifier) of the NCA of u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v. In [5] they present a label-NCA labeling scheme on trees enjoying Θ⁢(log⁡n)Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels.

In [39] they give a labeling scheme supporting the flow function on n𝑛nitalic_n-node general graphs using Θ⁢(log2⁡n+log⁡n⁢log⁡W)Θsuperscript2𝑛𝑛𝑊\Theta(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)roman_Θ ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W )-bit labels, where W𝑊Witalic_W is the maximum capacity of an edge. They also show a labeling scheme supporting the k𝑘kitalic_k-vertex-connectivity function on general graphs using O⁢(2k⁢log⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑘𝑛O(2^{k}\log n)italic_O ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n )-bit labels. See [30] for a survey on (static) labeling schemes.

Most of the research concerning labeling schemes in the dynamic settings considered the following two dynamic models on tree topologies. In the leaf-dynamic tree model, the topological event that may occur is that a leaf is either added to or removed from the tree. In the leaf-increasing tree model, the only topological event that may occur is that a leaf joins the tree.

A labeling schemes for the ancestry relation in the leaf-dynamic tree model is given in [19] using O⁢(n)𝑂𝑛O(n)italic_O ( italic_n )-bit labels. They assume that once a label is given to a node it remains unchanged. Therefore, the issue of updates is not considered even for the non distributed setting. Other labeling schemes are presented in the above paper assuming that clues about the future topology of the dynamic tree are given throughout the scenario.

The study of dynamic distributed labeling schemes was initiated in [42, 41]. In [42], a dynamic labeling scheme is presented for distances in the leaf-dynamic tree model with O⁢(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) label size and O⁢(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) amortized message complexity, where n𝑛nitalic_n is the current tree size. β𝛽\betaitalic_β-approximate distance labeling schemes (in which, given two labels, one can infer a β𝛽\betaitalic_β-approximation to the distance between the corresponding nodes) are presented [41]. Their schemes apply for dynamic models in which the tree topology is fixed but the edge weights may change.

Two general translation methods for extending static labeling schemes on trees to the dynamic setting are considered in the literature. Both approaches fit a number of natural functions on trees, such as ancestry, routing, label-NCA, id-NCA etc. Given a static labeling scheme on trees, in the leaf-increasing tree model, the resulting dynamic scheme in [42] incurs overheads (over the static scheme) of O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) in both the label size and the communication complexity. Moreover, if an upper bound nfsubscript𝑛𝑓n_{f}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the final number of vertices in the tree is known in advance, the resulting dynamic scheme in [42] incurs overheads (over the static scheme) of O⁢(log2⁡nf/log⁡log⁡nf)𝑂superscript2subscript𝑛𝑓subscript𝑛𝑓O(\log^{2}n_{f}/\log\log n_{f})italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / roman_log roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in the label size and only O⁢(log⁡n/log⁡log⁡n)𝑂𝑛𝑛O(\log n/\log\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ) in the communication complexity. In the leaf-dynamic tree model there is an extra additive factor of O⁢(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) to the amortized message complexity of the resulted schemes.

In [38], it is shown how to construct for many functions k⁢(x)𝑘𝑥k(x)italic_k ( italic_x ), a dynamic labeling scheme in the leaf-increasing tree model extending a given static scheme, such that the resulting scheme incurs overheads (over the static scheme) of O⁢(logk⁢(n)⁡n)𝑂subscript𝑘𝑛𝑛O(\log_{k(n)}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ) in the label size and O⁢(k⁢(n)⁢logk⁢(n)⁡n)𝑂𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛𝑛O(k(n)\log_{k(n)}n)italic_O ( italic_k ( italic_n ) roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ) in the communication complexity. As in [42], in the leaf-dynamic tree model there is an extra additive factor of O⁢(log2⁡n)𝑂superscript2𝑛O(\log^{2}n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) to the amortized message complexity of the resulted schemes. In particular, by setting k⁢(n)=nϵ𝑘𝑛superscript𝑛italic-ϵk(n)={n^{\epsilon}}italic_k ( italic_n ) = italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, dynamic labeling schemes are obtained with the same asymptotic label size as the corresponding static schemes and sublinear amortized message, namely, O⁢(nϵ)𝑂superscript𝑛italic-ϵO(n^{\epsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

1.1 Our contribution

We introduce the notion of f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling schemes with queries that is a natural generalization of the notion of f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling schemes. Using this notion we demonstrate that by increasing slightly the number of vertices whose labels are inspected, the size of the labels decreases considerably. Specifically, we inspect the labels of 3 vertices instead of 2, that is, we use a single query. In particular, we show that there exist simple labeling schemes with one query supporting the distance function on n𝑛nitalic_n-node trees as well as the flow function on n𝑛nitalic_n-node general graphs with label size O⁢(log⁡n+log⁡W)𝑂𝑛𝑊O(\log n+\log W)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_W ), where W𝑊Witalic_W is the maximum (integral) capacity of an edge. (We note that the lower bound for labeling schemes without queries for each of these problems is Ω⁢(log2⁡n+log⁡n⁢log⁡W)Ωsuperscript2𝑛𝑛𝑊\Omega(\log^{2}n+\log n\log W)roman_Ω ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + roman_log italic_n roman_log italic_W ) [32, 39].) We also show that there exists a labeling scheme with one query supporting the id-NCA function on n𝑛nitalic_n-node trees with label size O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ). (The lower bound for schemes without queries is Ω⁢(log2⁡n)Ωsuperscript2𝑛\Omega(\log^{2}n)roman_Ω ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n ) [51].) In addition, we show a routing labeling scheme with one query in the fixed-port model using O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels, while the lower bound (see [25]) for the case of no queries is Ω⁢(log2⁡nlog⁡log⁡n)Ωsuperscript2𝑛𝑛\Omega(\frac{\log^{2}n}{\log\log n})roman_Ω ( divide start_ARG roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ). We note that all the schemes we introduce have asymptotically optimal label size for schemes with one query. The matching lower bound proofs are straightforward in most of the cases, and we present the proofs in the remaining cases. Moreover, most of the results are obtained by simple constructions, which strengthens the motivation for this model.

We then show several extensions that are somewhat more involved. In particular, we show that our labeling schemes with queries on trees can be extended to the dynamic scenario using model translation methods based on those of [42, 38]. In order to save in the message complexity, we needed to make some adaptations to those methods, as well as to one of the static routing schemes of [24]. Second, we show that the study of the queries model can help with the traditional model too. That is, using ideas from our routing labeling scheme with one query, we show how to construct a 3-approximation routing scheme without queries for unweighted trees in the fixed-port model with Θ⁢(log⁡n)Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels.

Finally, we turn to a non-distributed environment and demonstrate similar constructions. That is, first, we show a simple method to transform previous results on NCA queries on static and dynamic trees in order to support also distance queries. Then, we show that one can preprocess a general weighted graph using almost linear space so that flow queries can be answered in almost constant time.

2 Preliminaries

Let T𝑇Titalic_T be a tree and let v𝑣vitalic_v be a vertex in T𝑇Titalic_T. Let d⁢e⁢g⁢(v)𝑑𝑒𝑔𝑣deg(v)italic_d italic_e italic_g ( italic_v ) denote the degree of v𝑣vitalic_v. For a non-root vertex v∈T𝑣𝑇v\in Titalic_v ∈ italic_T, let p⁢(v)𝑝𝑣p(v)italic_p ( italic_v ) denote the parent of v𝑣vitalic_v in T𝑇Titalic_T. In the case where the tree T𝑇Titalic_T is weighted (respectively, unweighted), the depth of a vertex is defined as its weighted (resp., unweighted) distance to the root. The nearest common ancestor of u𝑢uitalic_u and w𝑤witalic_w, N⁢C⁢A⁢(u,w)𝑁𝐶𝐴𝑢𝑤NCA(u,w)italic_N italic_C italic_A ( italic_u , italic_w ), is the common ancestor of both u𝑢uitalic_u and w𝑤witalic_w of maximum depth. Let 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) denote the family of all n𝑛nitalic_n-node unweighted trees. Let 𝒯⁢(n,W)𝒯𝑛𝑊{\cal T}(n,W)caligraphic_T ( italic_n , italic_W ) (respectively, 𝒢⁢(n,W)𝒢𝑛𝑊{\cal G}(n,W)caligraphic_G ( italic_n , italic_W )) denote the family of all n𝑛nitalic_n-node weighted trees (resp., connected graphs) with (integral) edge weights bounded from above by W𝑊Witalic_W.

Incoming and outgoing links from every node are identified by so called port-numbers. We distinguish between the following two variants of port models regarding routing schemes. In the designer port model the designer of the scheme can freely assign the port numbers of each vertex (as long as these port numbers are unique), and in the fixed-port model the port numbers at each vertex are assigned by an adversary. We assume that each port number is encoded using O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits.

2.1 The functions

We consider the following functions which are applied on pairs of vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v in a graph G=⟨V,E⟩𝐺𝑉𝐸G=\langle V,E\rangleitalic_G = ⟨ italic_V , italic_E ⟩. The detailed definitions of these functions are given in the appendix.
(1) flow (maximum legal flow between u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v), (2) distance (graph distance, either weighted, or unweighted), (3) routing (the port in u𝑢uitalic_u to the next vertex towards v𝑣vitalic_v). If the graph is a tree T𝑇Titalic_T then we consider also the following functions: (4) separation level (depth of N⁢C⁢A⁢(u,v)𝑁𝐶𝐴𝑢𝑣NCA(u,v)italic_N italic_C italic_A ( italic_u , italic_v )), (5) id-NCA, (6) label-NCA. In (5) above, it is assumed that identities containing O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits are assigned to the vertices by an adversary, and i⁢d−N⁢C⁢AT⁢(u,v)𝑖𝑑𝑁𝐶subscript𝐴𝑇𝑢𝑣id-NCA_{T}(u,v)italic_i italic_d - italic_N italic_C italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u , italic_v ) is the identity of N⁢C⁢A⁢(u,v)𝑁𝐶𝐴𝑢𝑣NCA(u,v)italic_N italic_C italic_A ( italic_u , italic_v ). In (6) above, it is assumed that each vertex can freely select its own identity (as long as all identities remain unique). In this case, the identities may also be referred to as labels.)

2.2 Labeling schemes and c𝑐citalic_c-query labeling schemes

Let f𝑓fitalic_f be a function defined on pairs of vertices of a graph. An f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme π=⟨ℳ,𝒟⟩𝜋ℳ𝒟\pi=\langle{\cal M},{\cal D}\rangleitalic_π = ⟨ caligraphic_M , caligraphic_D ⟩ for a family of graphs ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F is composed of the following components:

  1. 1.

    A marker algorithm ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M that given a graph G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F, assigns a label ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) to each vertex v∈G𝑣𝐺v\in Gitalic_v ∈ italic_G.

  2. 2.

    A (polynomial time) decoder algorithm 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}caligraphic_D that given the labels ℳ⁢(u)ℳ𝑢{\cal M}(u)caligraphic_M ( italic_u ) and ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) of two vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v in some graph G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F, outputs f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ).

The most common measure used to evaluate a labeling scheme π=⟨ℳ,𝒟⟩𝜋ℳ𝒟\pi=\langle{\cal M},{\cal D}\rangleitalic_π = ⟨ caligraphic_M , caligraphic_D ⟩, is the label size, i.e., the maximum number of bits used in a label ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) over all vertices v𝑣vitalic_v in all graphs G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F.

Let c𝑐citalic_c be some constant integer. Informally, in contrast to an f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme, in a c𝑐citalic_c-query f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme, given the labels of two vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v, the decoder may also consult the labels of c𝑐citalic_c other vertices. More formally, a c𝑐citalic_c-query f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme φ=⟨ℳ,Q,𝒟⟩𝜑ℳ𝑄𝒟\varphi=\langle{\cal M},Q,{\cal D}\rangleitalic_φ = ⟨ caligraphic_M , italic_Q , caligraphic_D ⟩ is composed of the following components:

  1. 1.

    A marker algorithm ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M that given a graph G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F, assigns a label ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) to each vertex v∈G𝑣𝐺v\in Gitalic_v ∈ italic_G. This label is composed of two sublabels, namely, ℳi⁢n⁢d⁢e⁢x⁢(v)superscriptℳ𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑥𝑣{\cal M}^{index}(v)caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_n italic_d italic_e italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v ) and ℳd⁢a⁢t⁢a⁢(v)superscriptℳ𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎𝑣{\cal M}^{data}(v)caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_a italic_t italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v ), where it is required that the index sublabels are unique, i.e., for every two vertices v𝑣vitalic_v and u𝑢uitalic_u, ℳi⁢n⁢d⁢e⁢x⁢(v)≠ℳi⁢n⁢d⁢e⁢x⁢(u)superscriptℳ𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑥𝑣superscriptℳ𝑖𝑛𝑑𝑒𝑥𝑢{\cal M}^{index}(v)\neq{\cal M}^{index}(u)caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_n italic_d italic_e italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_v ) ≠ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_n italic_d italic_e italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_u ). (In other words, the index sublabels can serve as identities.)

  2. 2.

    A (polynomial time) query algorithm Q𝑄Qitalic_Q that given the labels ℳ⁢(u)ℳ𝑢{\cal M}(u)caligraphic_M ( italic_u ) and ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) of two vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v in some graph G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F, outputs Q⁢(ℳ⁢(u),ℳ⁢(v))𝑄ℳ𝑢ℳ𝑣Q({\cal M}(u),{\cal M}(v))italic_Q ( caligraphic_M ( italic_u ) , caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) ) which is a set containing the indices (i.e., the first sublabels) of c𝑐citalic_c vertices in G𝐺Gitalic_G.

  3. 3.

    A (polynomial time) decoder algorithm 𝒟𝒟{\cal D}caligraphic_D that given the labels ℳ⁢(u)ℳ𝑢{\cal M}(u)caligraphic_M ( italic_u ) and ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) of two vertices u𝑢uitalic_u and v𝑣vitalic_v and the labels of the vertices in Q⁢(ℳ⁢(u),ℳ⁢(v))𝑄ℳ𝑢ℳ𝑣Q({\cal M}(u),{\cal M}(v))italic_Q ( caligraphic_M ( italic_u ) , caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) ), outputs f⁢(u,v)𝑓𝑢𝑣f(u,v)italic_f ( italic_u , italic_v ).

As in the case of f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling schemes, we evaluate a c𝑐citalic_c-query f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme φ=⟨ℳ,Q,𝒟⟩𝜑ℳ𝑄𝒟\varphi=\langle{\cal M},Q,{\cal D}\rangleitalic_φ = ⟨ caligraphic_M , italic_Q , caligraphic_D ⟩ by its label size, i.e, the maximum number of bits used in a label ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) over all vertices v𝑣vitalic_v in all graphs G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F. We note that all the schemes in this paper use c=1𝑐1c=1italic_c = 1, increasing the number of labels used by a smallest constant, while the size of the maximum label drops significantly in the order of magnitude. Let us comment also that clearly, since the index sublabels must be disjoint, any c𝑐citalic_c-query f𝑓fitalic_f-labeling scheme on any family of n𝑛nitalic_n-node graphs must have label size Ω⁢(log⁡n)Ω𝑛\Omega(\log n)roman_Ω ( roman_log italic_n ). See Section 7 for alternative definition for query labeling schemes.

2.3 Routing schemes and β𝛽\betaitalic_β-approximation routing schemes

A routing scheme is composed of a marker algorithm ℳℳ{\cal M}caligraphic_M for assigning each vertex v𝑣vitalic_v of a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G with a label ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ), coupled with a router algorithm ℛℛ{\cal R}caligraphic_R whose inputs are the header of a message, ℳ⁢(v)ℳ𝑣{\cal M}(v)caligraphic_M ( italic_v ) and the label ℳ⁢(y)ℳ𝑦{\cal M}(y)caligraphic_M ( italic_y ) of a destination vertex y𝑦yitalic_y. If a vertex x𝑥xitalic_x wishes to send a message to vertex y𝑦yitalic_y, it first prepares and attaches a header to the message. Then the router algorithm x𝑥xitalic_x outputs a port of x𝑥xitalic_x on which the message is delivered to the next vertex. This is repeated in every vertex until the message reaches the destination vertex y𝑦yitalic_y. Each intermediate vertex u𝑢uitalic_u on the route may replace the header of the message with a new header and may perform a local computation. The requirement is that the weighted length of resulting path connecting x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y is the same as the distance between x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y in G𝐺Gitalic_G.

For a constant β𝛽\betaitalic_β, a β𝛽\betaitalic_β-approximation routing scheme is the same as a routing scheme except that the requirement is that the length of resulting route connecting x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y is a β𝛽\betaitalic_β-approximation for the distance between x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y in G𝐺Gitalic_G.

In addition to the label size, we also measure a routing scheme (and a β𝛽\betaitalic_β-approximation routing scheme) by the header size, i.e., the maximum number of bits used in a header of a message.

3 Labeling schemes with one query

In this section we demonstrate that the query model allows for significantly shorter labels. In particular, we describe simple 1-query labeling schemes with labels that beat the lower bounds in the following well studied cases: for the family of n𝑛nitalic_n-node trees, schemes supporting the routing (in the fixed-port model), distance, separation level, and the id-NCA functions; for the family of n𝑛nitalic_n-node general graphs, a scheme supporting the flow function. We note that all the schemes we present use asymptotically optimal labels. The following lemma follows.

Lemma 3.1

The label size of a 1-query id-NCA labeling scheme on 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) is Θ⁢(log⁡n)normal-Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n ).

3.2 Distance and separation level in trees

The above method can be applied for other functions. We now show how to construct 1-query labeling schemes supporting the separation level and distance functions using similar method to the one described in Subsection 3.1. Both schemes are based on keeping the depth of a vertex in its data sublabel (instead of its identity). The correctness of the 1-query labeling scheme supporting the distance function is based on the following equation.

d⁢(v,u)=d⁢e⁢p⁢t⁢h⁢(v)+d⁢e⁢p⁢t⁢h⁢(u)−2⋅d⁢e⁢p⁢t⁢h⁢(N⁢C⁢A⁢(v,u)).𝑑𝑣𝑢𝑑𝑒𝑝𝑡ℎ𝑣𝑑𝑒𝑝𝑡ℎ𝑢⋅2𝑑𝑒𝑝𝑡ℎ𝑁𝐶𝐴𝑣𝑢d(v,u)=depth(v)+depth(u)-2\cdot depth(NCA(v,u)).italic_d ( italic_v , italic_u ) = italic_d italic_e italic_p italic_t italic_h ( italic_v ) + italic_d italic_e italic_p italic_t italic_h ( italic_u ) - 2 ⋅ italic_d italic_e italic_p italic_t italic_h ( italic_N italic_C italic_A ( italic_v , italic_u ) ) . (1)

The description of these schemes as well as the proof of the following lemma is deferred to the appendix.

Lemma 3.3

The label size of a 1-query labeling scheme supporting either the separation-level or the distance function on 𝒯⁢(n,W)𝒯𝑛𝑊{\cal T}(n,W)caligraphic_T ( italic_n , italic_W ) is Θ⁢(log⁡n+log⁡W)normal-Θ𝑛𝑊\Theta(\log n+\log W)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n + roman_log italic_W ).

Lemma 3.4

In the fixed-port model, the label size of a 1-query routing labeling scheme on 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) is Θ⁢(log⁡n)normal-Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n ).

4 3-approximation routing scheme in the fixed-port model (without queries)

By applying the method described in Subsection 3.3 to the traditional model, we now show how to construct a 3-approximation routing scheme (without queries) on 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ). Our 3-approximation routing labeling scheme πa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsubscript𝜋𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥\pi_{approx}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT operates in the fixed-port model and has label size and header size O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ). Recall that any (precise) routing scheme on 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) must have label size Ω⁢(log2⁡n/log⁡log⁡n)Ωsuperscript2𝑛𝑛\Omega(\log^{2}n/\log\log n)roman_Ω ( roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n / roman_log roman_log italic_n ) [25]. We note that our ideas for translating routing schemes from the designer port model to the fixed-port model implicitly appear in [1], however, a 3-approximation routing scheme (without queries) on 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) is not explicitly constructed there. The description of the 3-approximation routing labeling scheme πa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsubscript𝜋𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥\pi_{approx}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as the proof of the following lemma is deferred to the Appendix.

Lemma 4.1

πa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢xsubscript𝜋𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥\pi_{approx}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a correct 3-approximation routing scheme on 𝒯⁢(n)𝒯𝑛{\cal T}(n)caligraphic_T ( italic_n ) operating in the fixed port model. 5 Adapting the 1-query schemes on trees to the dynamic setting

In this section we show how to translate our 1-query labeling schemes on trees to the dynamic settings, i.e, to the leaf-increasing and leaf-dynamic tree models, [38, 42] (see also “Related work” in Section 1). In a dynamic scheme, the marker protocol updates the labels after every topological change. We show that the reduction in the label sizes obtained by introducing a single query in the dynamic scenario is similar to the reduction in the static case.

To describe the adaptation fully, we need to give many details about the methods of [42, 38, 24]. Unfortunately, this is not possible in this extended abstract. In our construction below, we just state and then use some facts about these methods. These facts can be proven easily given these methods.

The initial idea is to apply the methods introduced in [42, 38] to convert labeling schemes for static networks to work on dynamic networks too. Unfortunately, we cannot do this directly, since these methods were designed for traditional labeling schemes and not for 1-query labeling schemes.

The next idea is to perform the conversion indirectly. That is, recall (Section 3) that our 1-query labeling schemes utilize components that are schemes in the traditional model (with no queries). That is, some utilize πN⁢C⁢Asubscript𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴\pi_{NCA}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the label-NCA labeling scheme of [5] and some utilize πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the routing scheme of [24]. Hence, one can first convert these components to the dynamic setting. Second, one can attempt to use the resulted dynamic components in a similar way that we used the static components in Section 3. This turns out to be simple in the cases of the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions, but more involved in the case of the routing function.

In the case of the distance and separation level functions, πN⁢C⁢Asubscript𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴\pi_{NCA}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is used together with the depth of each vertex in its label. Hence, in the dynamic case, we need to update the depth with every topological change. In the dynamic models above, this uses only a constant number of messages per topological change, since once a vertex is added, its depth remains the same.

However, when trying to translate our 1-query routing labeling scheme to the dynamic settings, things turn out to be more difficult. Informally, the reason is the following. In φf⁢i⁢xsubscript𝜑𝑓𝑖𝑥\varphi_{fix}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, our static 1-query routing labeling scheme, each non-root vertex ‘knows’ the label assigned to its parent by another static routing scheme πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (see Section 3). When this scheme is made dynamic, the natural translation that enables the child to continue to ‘know’ the label of its parent is the following:
Notification: whenever the label of a non-leaf vertex changes, it notifies the new label to all the children. When a child receives such a notification message, it updates its φf⁢i⁢xsubscript𝜑𝑓𝑖𝑥\varphi_{fix}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT label accordingly (see Section 3).

In order to have an efficient translation, we need to account for the messages used for the above notification. This turns out to be relatively cheap when using the translation method of [42]. The relevant facts about [42] is the following: Theorem 4.16 and the fact that the label of a vertex v𝑣vitalic_v changes only as a part of changes in all the vertices of some subtree T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. These changes in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT involve Ω⁢(|T′|)Ωsuperscript𝑇′\Omega(|T^{\prime}|)roman_Ω ( | italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ) messages anyhow (not including the new notification messages required from v𝑣vitalic_v to its children). It so happened that in the method of [42], whenever a vertex v𝑣vitalic_v is included in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, all its children are included in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as well. Hence, the cost of the new notification messages can be amortized on the cost of the messages sent anyhow in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to perform the changes. Hence, we can (1) use the transformation of [42] to transform πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be dynamic, and then (2) use the new notification messages to implement φf⁢i⁢xsubscript𝜑𝑓𝑖𝑥\varphi_{fix}italic_φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f italic_i italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using the resulted dynamic version of πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This yields a dynamic routing scheme with 1-query enjoying the complexities promised in [42] (see part 2 in Theorem 5.1 below). It is still left to ensure parts 1 and 3 of Theorem 5.1 below. For that we need to use the transformation of [38], which turns out to be less easy.

To prove parts 1 and 3 of Theorem 5.1, the relevant fact about [38] consists of Theorems 1 and 2 of [38], and of the list of the cases where messages are sent. The latter is needed because we would like to show that we can amortize the cost of the new messages we now send, on the messages sent anyhow by the method of [38]. Unlike the case of [42], here messages are sent over a subtree that may include some vertex v𝑣vitalic_v, but not all of its children. Recall that our modifications includes the notification: sending messages from v𝑣vitalic_v, whose label was changed, to all of its children. When v𝑣vitalic_v has children outside of T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we cannot amortize the cost of the notification messages on the cost of the messages sent anyhow by the method of [38]. It turns out, however, that the only vertex in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that not all of its children are necessarily in T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the root r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of T′superscript𝑇′T^{\prime}italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, the notifications messages sent by a vertex v∈T′𝑣superscript𝑇′v\in T^{\prime}italic_v ∈ italic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where v≠r′𝑣superscript𝑟′v\neq r^{\prime}italic_v ≠ italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT do not increase the cost of the messages sent anyhow by the method of [38]. The only thing left to consider is the case where r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes its label in the dynamic labeling scheme given by the method of [38] applied on πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the static routing scheme of [24]. To bound the number of notification messages sent by r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we make sure that the label of r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT changes only when r′superscript𝑟′r^{\prime}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has at most 1 child. This is done by modifying the static routing scheme πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that when applying πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on any tree, the label given by πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to the root of the tree is always the same.

It therefore follows that the cost of the remaining notification messages can be amortized on the cost of the messages sent anyhow by [38]. The necessary modifications of the schemes, as well as the proof of the following theorem, appear in the appendix.

Theorem 5.1

Consider the fixed-port model and let k⁢(x)𝑘𝑥k(x)italic_k ( italic_x ) be any function satisfying that k⁢(x)𝑘𝑥k(x)italic_k ( italic_x ), logk⁢(x)⁡xsubscript𝑘𝑥𝑥\log_{k(x)}xroman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_x ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x and k⁢(x)log⁡k⁢(x)𝑘𝑥𝑘𝑥\frac{k(x)}{\log k(x)}divide start_ARG italic_k ( italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_k ( italic_x ) end_ARG are nondecreasing functions and that k⁢(Θ⁢(x))=Θ⁢(k⁢(x))𝑘normal-Θ𝑥normal-Θ𝑘𝑥k(\Theta(x))=\Theta(k(x))italic_k ( roman_Θ ( italic_x ) ) = roman_Θ ( italic_k ( italic_x ) ).111The above requirements are satisfied by most natural sublinear functions such as α⁢xϵ⁢logβ⁡x𝛼superscript𝑥italic-ϵsuperscript𝛽𝑥\alpha x^{\epsilon}\log^{\beta}xitalic_α italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x, α⁢logβ⁡log⁡x𝛼superscript𝛽𝑥\alpha\log^{\beta}\log xitalic_α roman_log start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_x etc.. There exist dynamic 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level, id-NCA and routing functions on trees with the following complexities.

  1. 1.

    In the leaf-increasing tree model, with label size O⁢(logk⁢(n)⁡n⋅log⁡n)𝑂subscript𝑘𝑛⋅𝑛𝑛O(\log_{k(n)}n\cdot\log n)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ⋅ roman_log italic_n ) and amortized message complexity O⁢(k⁢(n)⋅logk⁢(n)⁡n)𝑂⋅𝑘𝑛subscript𝑘𝑛𝑛O(k(n)\cdot\log_{k(n)}n)italic_O ( italic_k ( italic_n ) ⋅ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n ).

6 Applications in a non-distributed environments

In this section we first use ideas from our 1-query labeling schemes to translate previously known results on finding NCA in trees to support distance queries. We then use the translated scheme to show that general graphs can be preprocessed efficiently to support flow queries.

6.1 Distance queries in trees

Harel and Tarjan [36] describe a linear time algorithm to preprocess a tree and build a data structure allowing NCA queries to be answered in constant time on a RAM. Subsequently, simpler algorithms with better constant factors have been proposed in [53, 13, 28, 58, 14]. On a pointer machine, [36] show a lower bound of Ω⁢(log⁡log⁡n)Ω𝑛\Omega(\log\log n)roman_Ω ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) on the query time, which matches the upper bound of [60]. In the leaf-increasing tree model, [22, 10] show how to make updates in amortized constant time while keeping the constant worst-case query time on a RAM, or the O⁢(log⁡log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log\log n)italic_O ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) worst-case query time on a pointer machine. In [17] they show how to maintain the above mentioned results on a RAM in the leaf-dynamic tree model with worst case constant update. See [5] for a survey.

Simply by adding a pointer from each vertex to its depth and using Equation 1, we obtain the following lemma.

Lemma 6.1

The results of [36, 53, 13, 28, 58, 14, 36, 60, 22, 10, 17] can be translated to support either distance queries or separation level queries (instead of NCA queries).

We note that other types of dynamic models were studied in the non-distributed environment regarding NCA queries. See, for example, [17, 10]. However, in these types of topological changes, our transformation to distance queries is not efficient since any such changes may effect the depth of too many vertices.

6.2 Flow queries in general graphs

Recall that in in [39], they show how to construct a weighted tree T~G∈𝒯⁢(O⁢(n),W⋅n)subscript~𝑇𝐺𝒯𝑂𝑛⋅𝑊𝑛\tilde{T}_{G}\in{\cal T}(O(n),W\cdot n)over~ start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_T ( italic_O ( italic_n ) , italic_W ⋅ italic_n ) with n𝑛nitalic_n leaves v1,v2,⋯,vnsubscript𝑣1subscript𝑣2⋯subscript𝑣𝑛v_{1},v_{2},\cdots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋯ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that f⁢l⁢o⁢wG⁢(ui,uj)=s⁢e⁢p−l⁢e⁢v⁢e⁢lTG⁢(vi,vj)𝑓𝑙𝑜subscript𝑤𝐺subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗𝑠𝑒𝑝𝑙𝑒𝑣𝑒subscript𝑙subscript𝑇𝐺subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗flow_{G}(u_{i},u_{j})=sep-level_{T_{G}}(v_{i},v_{j})italic_f italic_l italic_o italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_s italic_e italic_p - italic_l italic_e italic_v italic_e italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). 7 Conclusion and open problems

In this paper we demonstrate that considering the labels of three vertices, instead of two, can lead to a significant reduction in the sizes of the labels. Inspecting two labels, and inspecting three, are approaches that lie on one end of a spectrum. On the other end of the spectrum would be a representation for which the decoder inspects the labels of all the nodes before answering (n𝑛nitalic_n-query labeling schemes). It is not hard to show that for any graph family ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F on n𝑛nitalic_n node graphs, and for many functions (for example, distance or adjacency), one can construct an n𝑛nitalic_n-query labeling scheme on ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F using asymptotically optimal labels, i.e, log⁡|ℱ|/n+Θ⁢(log⁡n)ℱ𝑛Θ𝑛\log|{\cal F}|/n+\Theta(\log n)roman_log | caligraphic_F | / italic_n + roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n )-bit labels (though the decoder may not be polynomial). The idea behind such a scheme is to enumerate the graphs in ℱℱ{\cal F}caligraphic_F arbitrarily. Then, given some G∈ℱ𝐺ℱG\in{\cal F}italic_G ∈ caligraphic_F whose number in this enumeration is i𝑖iitalic_i, distribute the binary representation of i𝑖iitalic_i among the vertices of G𝐺Gitalic_G. In this way, given the labels of all nodes, the decoder can reconstruct the graph and answer the desired query. Therefore, a natural question is to examine other points in this spectrum, i.e, examine c𝑐citalic_c-query labeling schemes for 1<c<n1𝑐𝑛1<c<n1 < italic_c < italic_n.

There are other dimensions to the above question. For example, by our definition, given the labels of two vertices, the c𝑐citalic_c vertices that are chosen by the query algorithm Q𝑄Qitalic_Q are chosen simultaneously. Alternatively, one may define a possibly stronger model in which these c𝑐citalic_c vertices are chosen one by one, i.e., the next vertex is determined using the knowledge obtained from the labels of previous vertices.

A.4 A 3-approximation routing scheme in the fixed port model

First note that in order to make sense, any routing scheme must have label size Ω⁢(log⁡n)Ω𝑛\Omega(\log n)roman_Ω ( roman_log italic_n ) since the labels must be distinct. Moreover, the header size of any routing scheme must also be Ω⁢(log⁡n)Ω𝑛\Omega(\log n)roman_Ω ( roman_log italic_n ) since the label of the destination vertex needs to be encoded in the header. We now construct our 3-approximation routing labeling scheme πa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x=⟨ℳa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x,ℛa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⟩subscript𝜋𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥subscriptℳ𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥subscriptℛ𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥\pi_{approx}=\langle{\cal M}_{approx},{\cal R}_{approx}\rangleitalic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⟨ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩, which operates in the fixed-port model and has label size and header size Θ⁢(log⁡n)Θ𝑛\Theta(\log n)roman_Θ ( roman_log italic_n ).

Lemma A.3

The routing scheme πa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x=⟨ℳa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x,ℛa⁢p⁢p⁢r⁢o⁢x⟩subscript𝜋𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥subscriptℳ𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥subscriptℛ𝑎𝑝𝑝𝑟𝑜𝑥\pi_{approx}=\langle{\cal M}_{approx},{\cal R}_{approx}\rangleitalic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ⟨ caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a italic_p italic_p italic_r italic_o italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⟩ is a 3333-approximation routing scheme.

Proof:  Let w𝑤witalic_w be the destination vertex. Any intermediate node u𝑢uitalic_u on the route delivers the message to its parent iff its parent is the next vertex on the shortest path connecting u𝑢uitalic_u and w𝑤witalic_w. Furthermore, if a vertex u𝑢uitalic_u delivers the message to its parent then the header of the message is set to ⟨ℳ⁢(w),0⟩ℳ𝑤0\langle{\cal M}(w),0\rangle⟨ caligraphic_M ( italic_w ) , 0 ⟩.

Any intermediate node u𝑢uitalic_u receiving the message with header ⟨ℳ⁢(w),x⟩ℳ𝑤𝑥\langle{\cal M}(w),x\rangle⟨ caligraphic_M ( italic_w ) , italic_x ⟩, where x≠0,−1𝑥01x\neq 0,-1italic_x ≠ 0 , - 1, deliverers the message to one of its children via port number x𝑥xitalic_x, where x𝑥xitalic_x is precisely the fixed-port number of the port at v𝑣vitalic_v whose designer port number is 𝒟d⁢e⁢s⁢(ℳd⁢e⁢s⁢(v),ℳd⁢e⁢s⁢(w))subscript𝒟𝑑𝑒𝑠subscriptℳ𝑑𝑒𝑠𝑣subscriptℳ𝑑𝑒𝑠𝑤{\cal D}_{des}({\cal M}_{des}(v),{\cal M}_{des}(w))caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) , caligraphic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) ). Therefore, the message is delivered to the next vertex on the shortest path connecting u𝑢uitalic_u and w𝑤witalic_w. Moreover, the message is delivered with the header ⟨ℳ⁢(w),0⟩ℳ𝑤0\langle{\cal M}(w),0\rangle⟨ caligraphic_M ( italic_w ) , 0 ⟩.

If u𝑢uitalic_u is the vertex initiating the route or if u𝑢uitalic_u is some intermediate node receiving the message with header ⟨ℳ⁢(w),0⟩ℳ𝑤0\langle{\cal M}(w),0\rangle⟨ caligraphic_M ( italic_w ) , 0 ⟩, where the next vertex on the shortest path from u𝑢uitalic_u to w𝑤witalic_w is one of u𝑢uitalic_u’s children, then precisely two messages are sent before the message returns to u𝑢uitalic_u with header ⟨ℳ⁢(w),x⟩ℳ𝑤𝑥\langle{\cal M}(w),x\rangle⟨ caligraphic_M ( italic_w ) , italic_x ⟩, where x≠0,−1𝑥01x\neq 0,-1italic_x ≠ 0 , - 1.

We therefore get that the resulting route from the initiator v𝑣vitalic_v to the destination w𝑤witalic_w is at most thrice as long as the shortest path connecting v𝑣vitalic_v and w𝑤witalic_w.    

Note that the label size of πd⁢e⁢ssubscript𝜋𝑑𝑒𝑠\pi_{des}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_e italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) and that each port number is encoded using O⁢(log⁡n)𝑂𝑛O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) bits. Therefore, using the previous lemma, we obtain Lemma 4.1

A.5 Sketch of the Proof of Theorem 5.1

The proof presented here in not completely self contained. A truely complete proof would include many details concerning three papers, namely, [24] and especially [42] and [38], and is, thus, too long to be given here.

We divide the proof into two parts. In the first part we consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions and in the second part we consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query routing labeling scheme.

A.5.1 First part of the proof

Let us first consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions. This part follows rather naturally from [42, 38].

Recall that in a query labeling scheme, the label of each vertex is composed of two sublabels, the index sublabel and the data sublabel. In our (static) 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions, the index sublabel of each vertex v𝑣vitalic_v is simply the label assigned to v𝑣vitalic_v by πN⁢C⁢Asubscript𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴{\pi}_{NCA}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the label-NCA labeling scheme of [5], and the data sublabel of v𝑣vitalic_v is either v𝑣vitalic_v’s depth or v𝑣vitalic_v’s identity. Therefore, we can dynamically maintain the index sublabel of each vertex using π^N⁢C⁢Asubscript^𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴\hat{\pi}_{NCA}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the dynamic label-NCA labeling scheme resulted by applying either Theorem 4.16 of [42] or Theorems 1 and 2 of [38] on πN⁢C⁢Asubscript𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴{\pi}_{NCA}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In addition, the data sublabel of each vertex v𝑣vitalic_v can easily be maintained as follows. In case we consider the id-NCA function, whenever a new vertex v𝑣vitalic_v joins the tree and an identity i⁢d⁢(v)𝑖𝑑𝑣id(v)italic_i italic_d ( italic_v ) is given to v𝑣vitalic_v by the adversary, this identity is stored at the data sublabel of v𝑣vitalic_v. If we consider, instead, either the distance or the separation level functions, the data sublabel of the root is set to be 0, and whenever a new vertex v𝑣vitalic_v joins the tree, it communicates with its parent p⁢(v)𝑝𝑣p(v)italic_p ( italic_v ) and sets its data sublabel to be ℳ^d⁢a⁢t⁢a⁢(v)=1+ℳ^d⁢a⁢t⁢a⁢(p⁢(v))subscript^ℳ𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎𝑣1subscript^ℳ𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎𝑝𝑣\hat{{\cal M}}_{data}(v)=1+\hat{{\cal M}}_{data}(p(v))over^ start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_a italic_t italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) = 1 + over^ start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_a italic_t italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ( italic_v ) ), where ℳ^d⁢a⁢t⁢a⁢(p⁢(v))subscript^ℳ𝑑𝑎𝑡𝑎𝑝𝑣\hat{{\cal M}}_{data}(p(v))over^ start_ARG caligraphic_M end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d italic_a italic_t italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p ( italic_v ) ) is the data sublabel given to p⁢(v)𝑝𝑣p(v)italic_p ( italic_v ) by our dynamic 1-query scheme. Therefore, each vertex v𝑣vitalic_v maintains its depth (or identity) in the its data sublabel with an extra constant additive cost to the amortized message complexity of π^N⁢C⁢Asubscript^𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴\hat{\pi}_{NCA}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

The query and decoder algorithms of the resulted dynamic 1-query labeling scheme relate to π^N⁢C⁢Asubscript^𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴\hat{\pi}_{NCA}over^ start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT similarly to the way the query and decoder algorithms of the corresponding static 1-query scheme relate to πN⁢C⁢Asubscript𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴{\pi}_{NCA}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since the labels of πN⁢C⁢Asubscript𝜋𝑁𝐶𝐴\pi_{NCA}italic_π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N italic_C italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be assigned by a distributed algorithm using O⁢(n)𝑂𝑛O(n)italic_O ( italic_n ) messages, Theorem 4.16 of [42] and Theorems 1 and 2 of [38] imply the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query labeling schemes supporting the distance, separation level and id-NCA functions.

A.5.2 Second part of the proof

We now consider the claims of Theorem 5.1 regarding the dynamic 1-query routing labeling scheme.
